ci_support_linux_64_r_base4.4.yaml:
c_compiler:
- gcc
c_compiler_version:
- '14'
c_stdlib:
- sysroot
c_stdlib_version:
- '2.17'
cdt_name:
- conda
channel_sources:
- conda-forge
channel_targets:
- conda-forge main
cran_mirror:
- https://cran.r-project.org
cxx_compiler:
- gxx
cxx_compiler_version:
- '14'
docker_image:
- quay.io/condaforge/linux-anvil-x86_64:alma9
fortran_compiler:
- gfortran
fortran_compiler_version:
- '14'
libblas:
- 3.9.* *netlib
pin_run_as_build:
  r-base:
    min_pin: x.x
    max_pin: x.x
r_base:
- '4.4'
target_platform:
- linux-64
zip_keys:
- - c_compiler_version
  - cxx_compiler_version
  - fortran_compiler_version

about.summary: Provides 'Scilab' 'n1qn1', or Quasi-Newton BFGS "qn" without constraints and 'qnbd' or Quasi-Newton BFGS with constraints. This takes more memory than traditional L-BFGS.  The n1qn1 routine is useful since it allows prespecification of a Hessian. If the Hessian is near enough the truth in optimization it can speed up the optimization problem. Both algorithms are described in the 'Scilab' optimization documentation located at <http://www.scilab.org/content/download/250/1714/file/optimization_in_scilab.pdf>.

Provides 'Scilab' 'n1qn1', or Quasi-Newton BFGS "qn" without constraints and 'qnbd' or Quasi-Newton BFGS with constraints. This takes more memory than traditional L-BFGS.  The n1qn1 routine is useful since it allows prespecification of a Hessian. If the Hessian is near enough the truth in optimization it can speed up the optimization problem. Both algorithms are described in the 'Scilab' optimization documentation located at <http://www.scilab.org/content/download/250/1714/file/optimization_in_scilab.pdf>.

name: r-n1qn1

about.summary: Provides 'Scilab' 'n1qn1', or Quasi-Newton BFGS "qn" without constraints and 'qnbd' or Quasi-Newton BFGS with constraints. This takes more memory than traditional L-BFGS.  The n1qn1 routine is useful since it allows prespecification of a Hessian. If the Hessian is near enough the truth in optimization it can speed up the optimization problem. Both algorithms are described in the 'Scilab' optimization documentation located at <http://www.scilab.org/content/download/250/1714/file/optimization_in_scilab.pdf>.

raw_meta_yaml:
{% set version = "6.0.1-12" %}
{% set posix = 'm2-' if win else '' %}

package:
  name: r-n1qn1
  version: {{ version|replace("-", "_") }}

source:
  url:
    - {{ cran_mirror }}/src/contrib/n1qn1_{{ version }}.tar.gz
    - {{ cran_mirror }}/src/contrib/Archive/n1qn1/n1qn1_{{ version }}.tar.gz
  sha256: 622c54b40d688a4ca9c0c8580a678bfbf0ed9320696432c5024ce5cd55ddf5e5

build:
  number: 1
  rpaths:
    - lib/R/lib/
    - lib/

requirements:
  build:
    - {{ compiler('c') }}              # [not win]
    - {{ stdlib('c') }}              # [not win]
    - {{ compiler('m2w64_c') }}        # [win]
    - {{ stdlib('m2w64_c') }}        # [win]
    - {{ compiler('cxx') }}            # [not win]
    - {{ compiler('m2w64_cxx') }}      # [win]
    - {{ compiler('fortran') }}        # [not win]
    - {{ compiler('m2w64_fortran') }}  # [win]
    - {{ posix }}filesystem        # [win]
    - {{ posix }}make
    - {{ posix }}sed               # [win]
    - {{ posix }}coreutils         # [win]
    - {{ posix }}zip               # [win]
  host:
    - libblas                # [unix]
    - r-base
    - r-rcpp >=0.12.3
    - r-rcpparmadillo >=0.5.600.2.0
  run:
    - libblas                # [unix]
    - r-base
    - r-rcpp >=0.12.3
    - r-rcpparmadillo >=0.5.600.2.0

test:
  commands:
    - $R -e "library('n1qn1')"           # [not win]
    - "\"%R%\" -e \"library('n1qn1')\""  # [win]

about:
  home: https://github.com/nlmixrdevelopment/n1qn1
  license: CECILL-2.0
  license_file: LICENCE
  summary: Provides 'Scilab' 'n1qn1', or Quasi-Newton BFGS "qn" without constraints and 'qnbd' or Quasi-Newton BFGS with constraints. This takes more memory than traditional L-BFGS.  The n1qn1 routine is useful since it allows prespecification of a Hessian. If the Hessian is near enough the truth in optimization it can speed
    up the optimization problem. Both algorithms are described in the 'Scilab' optimization documentation located at <http://www.scilab.org/content/download/250/1714/file/optimization_in_scilab.pdf>.

extra:
  recipe-maintainers:
    - conda-forge/r

# Package: n1qn1
# Title: Port of the 'Scilab' 'n1qn1' and 'qnbd' Modules for (Un)constrained BFGS Optimization

The n1qn1 routine is useful since it allows prespecification of a Hessian. If the Hessian is near enough the truth in optimization it can speed up the optimization problem. Both algorithms are described in the 'Scilab' optimization documentation located at <http://www.scilab.org/content/download/250/1714/file/optimization_in_scilab.pdf>.

about.summary: Provides 'Scilab' 'n1qn1', or Quasi-Newton BFGS "qn" without constraints and 'qnbd' or Quasi-Newton BFGS with constraints. This takes more memory than traditional L-BFGS.  The n1qn1 routine is useful since it allows prespecification of a Hessian. If the Hessian is near enough the truth in optimization it can speed up the optimization problem. Both algorithms are described in the 'Scilab' optimization documentation located at <http://www.scilab.org/content/download/250/1714/file/optimization_in_scilab.pdf>.
